speaker: Neil
text: Hello. This is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I’m Neil.

speaker: Sam
text: And I’m Sam. What’s the matter, Neil? You sound upset.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, I am, Sam - I just spent an hour working on my computer when it suddenly froze. I lost everything and had to start all over again!

speaker: Sam
text: Agghh, that’s so frustrating - like pop-up internet ads and buffering videos that never play!

speaker: Neil
text: Modern computers and the internet have revolutionised the way we live today, bringing us the world with a click of a button. But not everyone feels happy about these technological developments.

speaker: Sam
text: While potentially acting as a force for good and progress, the internet also provides a way of spreading hate and misinformation. And for some people, the World Wide Web remains a mysterious and confusing place.

speaker: Neil
text: In this programme, we’ll hear about a new academic subject called Web Science. Web Science studies the technology behind the internet.

speaker: Sam
text: But from the human side, it’s also interested in how people interact with each other online. So we’ll be asking whether studying Web Science could make the internet better for humanity in the future.

speaker: Neil
text: But first it’s time for our quiz question. I wonder what the pioneers of the internet would think about how it is used today. So the question is, who invented the World Wide Web? Was it:

speaker: Neil
text: a) Bill Gates,

speaker: Neil
text: b) Tim Berners-Lee,  or

speaker: Neil
text: c) Steve Jobs

speaker: Sam
text: Well, Bill Gates and Steve Jobs were the brains behind Microsoft and Apple Mac, so I’m going to say c) Tim Berners-Lee.

speaker: Neil
text: OK, Sam, we’ll find out later. Now, because of coronavirus the annual Web Science conference was held online this year. Its theme was ‘making the web human-centric’.

speaker: Sam
text: One of the conference’s key speakers, and co-founder of the new discipline of Web Science, was Dame Wendy Hall. Here she is speaking to BBC World Service’s Digital Planet:

speaker: social media networksecosysteminterdisciplinary
text: People think about the web as a technology but actually it’s co-createdby society. We put the content on, we interact with the technology, with the platforms, with the social media networks to create it. What we study is how that works as an ecosystem,this coming together of people and technology, and it’s very interdisciplinary, very socio-technical, and of course these days a lot of it is powered by AI.

speaker: interdisciplinary
text: Web Science is not only interested in the technology side of the internet. As a subject it’s very interdisciplinary - involving two or more academic subjects or areas of knowledge. Web Science combines digital technology with subjects ranging from psychology and robotics to economics and sociology.

speaker: social media networks
text: Exchanges between humans and the internet can be seen in social media networks - websites, apps and computer programmes, like Facebook and Instagram, which allow people to use electronic devices to communicate and share information.

speaker: ecosystem
text: This view of technology sees the internet as an ecosystem – a complex pattern of relationships and mutual influences that exists between all living things and their environment.

speaker: Sam
text: One ongoing and topical example of websites helpfully interacting with humans is the Covid contact tracing app.

speaker: Neil
text: You might think the mobile phone app, which tracks movements and contact between people to combat coronavirus, would be a useful practical application of internet technology.

speaker: Sam
text: But as Carly Kind, Director of the Ada Lovelace Institute in Cambridge, explained to BBC World Service’s Digital Planet, things are never that straightforward:

speaker: doing what it says on the tin trailspublic health
text: Actually, there’s a lot of more fundamental questions that haven’t been answered yet such as: is Bluetooth even an adequate mechanism for doing what it says on the tin, which is detecting contact between two people? The trails so far show that it’s not actually that great and so, do we know for sure that these apps work and they work in the way we want them to? Do we get the public health information that we need?

speaker: public health -
text: Apps like this are designed to support public health - services to improve the standard of health of a country’s general population.

speaker: do what it says on the tin
text: But Carly thinks the mechanisms used must be suitable and adequate – they must actually work or do what it says on the tin – an informal idiom meaning work exactly as it is intended to.

speaker: trials
text: To find this out, trials - tests to discover how effective or suitable something is - are carried out over a period of time.

speaker: Sam
text: The kind of trials which were carried out during the invention of the internet in the first place, right, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Ah yes, the invention of the internet – or to be more accurate, the World Wide Web. In our quiz question I asked you who invented the World Wide Web? What did you say, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: I said b) Tim Berners-Lee.

speaker: Neil
text: Well, you’re a first class web scientist, Sam, because that’s the correct answer!

speaker: interdisciplinary  ecosystem
text: Great! In this programme, we’ve been hearing about Web Science, a new interdisciplinary subject, combining several areas of study, which investigates the ecosystem of the internet – the complex pattern of interconnections between humans and their environment.

speaker: Social media networks
text: Social media networks –websites and apps, like Facebook, which let people use electronic devices to communicate on the internet – show how humans and technology can successfully interact.

speaker: trialsdoes what it says on the tin
text: A new Covid contact tracing app is currently undergoing trials – tests to see if it works effectively. This will discover if it does what it says on the tin – works as it’s supposed to.

speaker: public health
text: If successful, by alerting people to coronavirus risks the app will support public health – services aimed at improving the health of the general population.

speaker: Sam
text: And that’s all from us for now.

speaker: Neil
text: And we hope you’ll join us again soon for more topical English vocabulary here at 6 Minute English. Bye for now!

speaker: Sam
text: Bye bye!
